questions.text: What would be appropriate pre-operative investigations needed in a patient going for elective hernia surgery who has hypertension and is on ace inhibitor and has undergone Coronary Artery Bypass surgery 4 years back?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
• CARDIOVASCULAR COMPLICATIONS are the major causes of perioperative morbidity and
mortality, with myocardial infarctions occurring in 1% to 3% of unselected patients undergoing major
noncardiac surgery
• There is an increased incidence of cardiac disease and comorbidities in older patients undergoing
elective non cardiac surgery
• Preoperative optimization is essential to decrease the risk of postoperative Major Adverse Cardiac
Events (MACE).
• The ACC/AHA guidelines provide a suitable framework for evaluating cardiac risk
• This is based on the presence of potentially serious cardiac disorders including CAD, congestive
heart failure, valvular heart disease, and arrhythmias.
• The preoperative cardiac evaluation for noncardiac surgery also emphasizes the patient’s
functional status and understanding the surgical risk.
• This risk assessment allows physicians to assign a clinical risk profile to an individual patient,
which allows cardiologists, anaesthesiologists, and surgeons to make informed treatment decisions
that may influence short-term and long-term cardiovascular outcomes

questions.text: Which drug is used post operatively to regain strength from muscular weakness?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) • Most common used muscle relaxants during surgery are non-depolarising muscle relaxants. • These agents are competitive inhibitors of nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at post junctional muscle membrane. • During recovery from their action, use of anticholinesterase agents can increase the effective concentration of acetylcholine around the receptor and so will reverse the block. • 3 commonly used drugs for this purpose are: neostigmine, physostigmine and edrophonium. • These anticholinesterase drugs are always given with an anti-cholinergic drug eg atropine \ glycopyrrolate to prevent the muscarinic side effects of these agents.

choices.text: Spontaneous breathing under the effect of muscle relaxation

questions.text: Identify the capnogram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
• This is a typical capnogram of 1st spontaneous breath under the effect of muscle relaxation.
• There is a notch \ dip in the expiratory plateau phase of the capnogram called as curare notch \
cleft.

questions.text: Anesthetic gas with maximum respiratory irritation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Desflurane is known for causing the maximum respiratory irritation among commonly used inhalational anesthetic agents. It is associated with a pungent odor and can lead to coughing, breath-holding, laryngospasm, and increased airway secretions, particularly during induction of anesthesia. This is due to its low blood-gas solubility and rapid onset, which can cause a sudden increase in alveolar concentration, irritating the airway mucosa. Because of this, desflurane is typically avoided for inhalational induction, especially in pediatric or sensitive patients, and is more often used for maintenance of anesthesia once the airway is secured.

questions.text: IV administration of which anesthetic drug is most painful among the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Etomidate is known to cause significant pain on intravenous (IV) injection, more so than most other anesthetic agents. This pain is likely due to the drug’s formulation in a propylene glycol solution or lipid emulsion, which can irritate the vein walls. Patients often report burning or stinging sensations immediately upon administration. In clinical practice, the pain can be reduced by prior injection of lidocaine or using a larger vein. Despite its painful injection, etomidate is favored in certain situations (like hemodynamic instability) due to its minimal cardiovascular effects.

questions.text: Which of the following is not cardio depressive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Etomidate is not cardiodepressive, making it the correct answer. It is unique among intravenous anesthetic agents because it has minimal cardiovascular effects. It maintains stable heart rate, cardiac output, and blood pressure, which makes it the induction agent of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients or those with compromised cardiac function. Etomidate achieves anesthesia without significant myocardial depression or vasodilation, which is why it's frequently used in emergency and critical care settings for induction.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common method used to know depth of anesthesia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The Bispectral Index (BIS) is the most commonly used method to assess the depth of anesthesia in modern clinical practice. BIS is a quantitative EEG-based monitoring tool that gives a numerical value (typically between 0 and 100) reflecting the patient's level of consciousness. A BIS value of 40–60 is generally targeted during general anesthesia, indicating an adequate depth for surgical procedures without awareness. BIS helps in titrating anesthetic drugs accurately, reducing the risk of both underdosing (awareness) and overdosing (excessive sedation and complications), and is especially useful in high-risk or long-duration surgeries.

choices.text: Activation of GABA receptors in brain

questions.text: Mechanism of action of curare is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Curare acts as a competitive antagonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) located at the neuromuscular junction. It competes with acetylcholine (ACh) for binding to these receptors but does not activate them, thereby preventing depolarization of the muscle end-plate and leading to skeletal muscle paralysis. This mechanism underlies the use of curare and its derivatives (like tubocurarine) as non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agents in anesthesia to induce muscle relaxation during surgery. Since it is competitive, its effects can be reversed by increasing ACh levels using cholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine.

choices.text: Less potent and so less laudonosine production

questions.text: Cisatracurium is preferred over atracurium because?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cisatracurium is preferred over atracurium primarily because it causes minimal to no histamine release, making it safer and more hemodynamically stable, especially in patients who are prone to hypotension or bronchospasm. Atracurium can lead to histamine-mediated side effects such as hypotension, flushing, and bronchospasm, which are not desirable during anesthesia. Cisatracurium is a more refined stereoisomer of atracurium and retains similar efficacy as a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker, but with a cleaner side effect profile, particularly due to the lack of significant histamine release.

questions.text: Best marker to know whether ET tube is in correct position: -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Confirmation of placement of tube:
• Tracheal intubation is one of the essential medical procedures.
• Unrecognised or accidental endobronchial intubation results in hypoventilation and collapse of the
non-ventilated lung, barotrauma or pneumothorax in the ventilated
lung.
• Unrecognised oesophageal intubation can lead to severe morbidity like hypoxic brain damage.
• Therefore, verification of correct positioning of endotracheal tube (ETT) is essential to avoid
serious consequences.
Various methods have been described to identify the correct position of ETT like:
1. Intubation under direct vision
2. Inspection of chest wall movements
3. Auscultation of bilateral breath sounds
4. Monitoring of end-tidal carbon dioxide (EtCO2)
5. Use of negative pressure devices
6. Fibreoptic bronchoscopy

7. Chest X-ray.
Among all, though capnography is considered the most commonly used method, but it may not be
reliable under certain conditions, e.g., endobronchial intubation, poor circulatory perfusion as in
cardiac arrest, severe hypotension, pulmonary embolism, severe bronchospasm, poor pulmonary
reserve like pleural effusion, pneumothorax and pulmonary malignancy.
Prior bag-mask ventilation leading to gastric insufflation, antacid consumption or ingestion of
carbonated beverages also may lead to false positive results with capnography.

questions.text: What manoeuvre is shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Head Tilt/Chin Lift
• The head tilt/chin lift is one of the most common active maneuvers used to open a patient's
airway.
• This maneuver should be used only if the clinician is confident that there is no risk of cervical
spine injury.
• Standing on the side of the patient, the clinician places one hand on the patient's forehead while
simultaneously placing the fingers of the other hand under the patient's mandible.
• The head is then tilted backward while lifting the mandible forward, extending the neck.
• This action creates an open airway by lifting the tongue from the posterior pharynx.
• If effectively applied, the head-tilt/chin-lift maneuver may allow the patient to resume
unobstructed breathing without further intervention.

Jaw thrust:
The jaw thrust is preferred over the above mentioned techniques in known or suspected cases of
cervical spine injuries because the head and neck remain in a more neutral position when it is
applied.
When performing a jaw-thrust maneuver, the clinician stands behind the head of the patient, places
the fingers of both hands on the left and right sides under the angles of the mandible, and applies
forward and upward pressure (Fig.).
As with the head tilt/chin lift, the jaw-thrust maneuver displaces the tongue from the posterior
pharynx, but does so while keeping the patient's head and neck in a neutral position, and may allow
the patient to resume unobstructed breathing without further intervention.

questions.text: Patient was under anesthesia with halothane for maintenance agent and he developed hyperthermia. What additional drug can be the cause this effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Malignant hyperthermia:
• it’s a rare genetic hyper metabolic muscle disorder due to mutation in gene coding for ryanodine
receptors on chromosome 19.
• It’s a trigger-based event with certain anesthetic agents being the most common triggers.
• All inhaled anesthetic agents except nitrous oxide and xenon trigger malignant hyperthermia and
amongst muscle relaxants succinyl choline causes it.
• Drug of choice for treatment of MH is iv dantrolene.

questions.text: While doing lumbar puncture, which layer will be punctured last before piercing the lumbar cistern :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Structures pierced during lumbar puncture \ sub arachnoid block:
From outside to inside:
1. Skin
2. Subcutaneous tissue
3. Supraspinous ligament
4. Interspinous ligament
5. Ligamentum flavum

6. Dura
7. Arachnoid

questions.text: A patient underwent cardiovascular collapse following a regional anesthetic block with bupivacaine, what would be the immediate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST):
• When blood concentration of local anesthetic agent reaches beyond a certain limit then it causes
systemic toxicity called as LAST.
Etiology:
1: excessive \ toxic dose of local anesthetic agent given.
2: accidental intravascular placement of the local anesthetic while giving a regional block.
There are 2 forms of LAST:
1: central nervous system toxicity: early and mild
2: cardiovascular system toxicity: late and grave
Most cardiotoxic LA is Bupivacaine,
Treatment of choice for bupivacaine induced cardiotoxicity is 20% INTRALIPID solution which
increases the rate of recovery of blocked sodium channels from the cardiac myocytes.

questions.text: What is the frequency of stimulus in tetanic stimulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

It’s a pattern of stimulation where there is continuous stimulation of nerve.
The frequency of stimulation ranges from 50-200 hz
Tetanic stimulation is used to assess Post Tetanic Count (PTC).

choices.text: Binding to sodium channels and causing their inactivation

questions.text: Mechanism of Action of local anaesthetics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
• Local anesthetics bind a specific region of the α subunit and inhibit voltage-gated Na channels,
preventing channel activation and inhibiting the Na influx associated with membrane depolarization.
• With increasing local anesthetic concentrations, an increasing fraction of the Na channels in the
membrane bind a local anesthetic molecule and cannot conduct Na ions as consequence, impulse
conduction slows, the rate of rise and the magnitude of the action potential decrease, and the
threshold for excitation and impulse conduction increases progressively.

• At high enough local anesthetic concentrations and with a sufficient fraction of local anestheticbound
Na channels, an action potential can no longer be generated, and impulse propagation is
abolished.
• Local anesthetics have a greater affinity for the channel in the open or inactivated state than in
the resting state. (AIIMSQ)
• Local anesthetic binding to Na channels does not alter the resting membrane potential. (NEETQ)

questions.text: Most common cause of admission after day care surgery:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Pain is the most common cause of unplanned hospital admission after day care surgery.
2nd most common cause is complications associated with opioid use for pain i.e respiratory
complications and post operative nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: Maximum FiO2 is delivered by which device?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.text: What is the size of the cannula shown in the image below:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: A person was infected with covid 19 and was symptomatic but didn’t not require hospitalization. After how long can he undergo elective surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A)

questions.text: Which of the following is a sole high potency inhaled anesthetic agent that can be used for both induction and endotracheal intubation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
• One main disadvantage of halothane is its high blood:gas partition coefficient, which leads to
relatively long induction times.
• It also can produce cardiac dysrhythmias, myocardial depression, and halothane-induced
hepatitis.
• Because of the inability to achieve deep levels of anesthesia with halothane because of its side
effects, the use of NMBDs, opioids, or both, is often required

questions.text: 20 % Intralipid bolus was administered during resuscitation. Why?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Treatment of local anesthetic systemic toxicity: cardio toxicity
• Drug of choice is infusion of 20% INTRALIPID solution: bolus dose : 1.5 ml/kg followed by infusion
of 0.25 ml \kg\min
• Mechanism: it increases the rate of recovery of blocked sodium channels by decreasing cardiac
bupivacaine concentration.
• No other antiarrhythmic is useful
• Use of lignocaine is not recommended.
• 2 drugs useful are adrenaline and amiodarone as per ACLS guidelines for the management of
cardiac arrest
• Later in severe cases extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) can be used.

questions.text: Maximum flow rate of oxygen that can be used by conventional oxygen therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
• Conventional oxygen therapy (COT) is the main supportive treatment administered to patients
after planned extubation and has conventionally been delivered using nasal prongs, cannula or
masks.
• However, the maximal oxygen flow rates that these devices can deliver are limited.
• The maximal oxygen flow rate delivered by COT is only 15 L/min, which is far lower than the
demands of post extubation patients with acute respiratory failure.
• Therefore, ambient air dilutes the supplied oxygen, and finally, the fraction of inspired oxygen
(FiO2) is significantly reduced in the alveoli.
• Furthermore, with oxygen delivered by COT, it is difficult to meet the requirements of heating and
humidification in these patients.
• High-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) can supply a mixture of air and oxygen via a heated and
humidified circuit at a very high flow.
• It can provide almost pure oxygen with a FiO2 of approximately 100% and a maximal flow rate up
to 60 L/min.
• The use of a HFNC may generate a positive airway pressure, ameliorate oxygenation and
dyspnoea, reduce the respiratory rate and work of breathing, and improve comfort

questions.text: ASA I patient posted for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During surgery, sudden drop in ETCO2 to 8 mm hg with hypotension and tachycardia but airway pressures were 18cm H20. What’s the diagnosis? 1) CO2 embolism 2) Pneumothorax 3) bronchospasm 4) single bronchus intubation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
• The proposed mechanisms of gas embolism include inadvertent intravenous placement of the
Veress needle or passage of CO2 into the abdominal wall and peritoneal vessels during insufflation or
into open vessels on the liver surface during gallbladder dissection.
• Most of the embolisms during laparoscopic hysterectomy occur during round ligament transection
and broad ligament Dissection
• Signs and severity of the effects of CO2 embolism are variable and may include cardiac
arrhythmia, hypoxemia, and hypotension, and an associated decrease in ETCO2.
• The electrocardiogram might show a right strain pattern and widening of the QRS complex.
• Cyanosis of the head and neck resulting from in low obstruction to the right side of the heart may
also occur.
• Paradoxical embolism through a patent foramen ovale or an atrial septal defect may result in
cerebral CO2 embolism.

questions.text: Identify the reading:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Capnography is a measure of End Tidal CO2 concentration in mmhg along with its graphical
representation.
Capnography is one of the essential monitors during anesthesia esp general anesthesia and is an
indicator of both respiration and circulation during anesthesia.
